newsitem.title: TURKMENISTAN: Turkmen 97 grain harvest only half official target.
newsitem.headline: Turkmen 97 grain harvest only half official target.

text.p: Turkmenistan has harvested a paltry 600,000 tonnes of grain in 1997, or half the official target, and President Saparmurat Niyazov has sacked officials he said were responsible.
Turkmenistan gathered just 50.6 percent of the initially targeted 1.2 million tonnes, the State Statistics Committee said in its preliminary report on Wednesday.
But output was still up on last year's paltry 480,000 tonnes.
The committee said the figures could be slightly corrected later, but that would not change the overall picture.

The meagre harvest gathered this year is the second failed attempt in a row by the resource-rich but impoverished country with a population of around four million to achieve self-sufficiency in grain.
Like last year, Niyazov, who enjoys sweeping executive powers, has sacked what he calls the culprits.

Among those sacked this year are Pirkuli Odeyev, Agriculture Minister and acting Deputy Prime Minister, Nurmukhammed Ashirov, governor of the country's main grain-growing Alkal region, and numerous district heads of the same region.

"Good undertakings of peasants have been blocked by the bureaucracy of the authorities," Niyazov thundered on national television on Tuesday. "It is abnormal to gather such poor harvests in the region with fertile lands and irrigation."
In April he presented his own ambitious economic programme, setting the production of 2.0 million tonnes of grain by 2000 as one of Turkmenistan's main economic tasks.
But so far the secretive, impoverished nation, where serious economic reforms have been delayed, has been heavily relying on grain imports.
Last year Turkmenistan imported $800 million of grain, according to the official Turkmen Press news agency.
